frontmatter.title: Being -small
frontmatter.meta: Defn. 1 from de Jong and Escard贸

mainmatter.p: Let \mathcal{U} and \mathcal{V} be two universes. A type X : \mathcal{U} is called \mathcal{V}-small if it has a copy in universe \mathcal{V}, which is to say \mathsf{hasSize} ( X , \mathcal{V} ) \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{ Y \ : \ \mathcal{V} } X \simeq Y .
Let \mathcal{U} and \mathcal{V} be two universes. The propositional ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} )-resizing axiom says that every proposition P : \mathcal{U} is \mathcal{V}-small.

frontmatter.title: The 惟 (, )-resizing axiom
frontmatter.meta: Defn 2.ii from de Jong and Escard贸

mainmatter.p: Let \mathcal{U} and \mathcal{V} be two universes. The \Omega ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} )-resizing axiom says that the type \Omega _{ \mathcal{U} } is \mathcal{V}-small.

frontmatter.title: Predicative Aspects of Order Theory in Univalent Foundations
frontmatter.meta: @InProceedings{tdj-mhe-aspects, author = {de Jong, Tom and Escard\'o, Mart\'in H\"otzel}, title = {Predicative Aspects of Order Theory in Univalent Foundations}, booktitle = {6th International Conference on Formal Structures for Computation and Deduction (FSCD 2021)}, pages = {8:1--8:18}, series = {Leibniz International Proceedings in Informatics (LIPIcs)}, year = 2021, volume = 195, editor = {Kobayashi, Naoki}, publisher = {Schloss Dagstuhl--Leibniz-Zentrum f\"ur Informatik}, doi = {10.4230/LIPIcs.FSCD.2021.8}, }
